Homeotic genes also known a homebox genes are not the same as HOX genes as u stated at 2:54. They are different.  A homeobox is a sequence of DNA within a gene.  The protein that results from the gene will will include a small number of amino acids that are dictated by the homeobox sequence. This part of the protein is known as the homeobox domain (or just homeodomain).   The importance of the homeodomain is that this is the part of a protein that can interact directly with DNA (or RNA). So, proteins that contain a homeodomain can act as transcription factors. Equivalently, genes that contain a homeobox sequence can be regulatory genes.   Hox genes are simply one group of genes that contain a homeobox sequence, and which are very important in body plan development. However, there are plenty of other genes that are not hox genes and also contain a homeobox sequence.

If you think of evolution as a continuity of experiences, it is possible to "remember" what you already experienced but not to "predict" what hasn't happened yet.  This "past experience" is not the only force of evolution. Natural selection and more gradual mutation from environmental stimuli provides those "new experiences" that we "remember" going forward, but cannot be passed on to those who do not share in the experience.

MG42pillbox I agree 100% with Kayleigh but if you want to know how pollinating insects coevolved with Angiosperms (flowering plants) please read the below: Early gymnosperms and angiosperms were wind-pollinated. Like modern gymnosperms, the ovule exuded droplets of sap to catch pollen grains.  Insects (beetles) on the plant found this protein/sugar mix and used it as food. Insects became dependent on this food source and started carrying pollen from plant to plant. Beetle-pollination must have been more efficient than wind for some species, so there was natural selection for plants that attracted insects. Next to occur would have been the evolution of nectaries, nectar-secreting structures, to lure the pollinators. Development of white or brightly-colored, conspicuous flowers to draw attention to the nectar and/or other food sources would also have occurred. The carpel (female reproductive structure) was originally leaf-shaped. It became folded on itself to enclose and protect the ovule from being eaten by the pollinators (hence Angiosperms). Plants with protected ovules would have been selected over ones with ovules that got eaten because the ones that got eaten could not have offspring. By the beginning of the Cenozoic Era (65 mya), the first bees, wasps, butterflies, and moths had evolved. The significance in this is that these are insects for which flowers are often the only source of nutrition for the adults. From this point on, certain plant and insect species have had a profound influence on one another’s evolution. A flower that attracted specific pollinators on a regular basis had an advantage (less wasted pollen) over flowers that attracted “promiscuous” pollinators. It is also an advantage for the pollinator to have its own “private” food source because there is, thus, less competition. The varied shapes, colors, and odors of flowers allowed sensory recognition by pollinators and excluded unwanted, indiscriminate pollinators. Today, over 65% of Angiosperms are insect-pollinated and 20% of insects, at least at some stage, depend on flowers for their food.

It didn't "just happen". Genetic mutations (especially the "good guy" ones that are incredibly freakin' rare) accumulate over a long time, so an organism - or, should I say, a species - acquires feathers over a few hundred million years. Give or take, I don't know. The feathers stay because either a) they proved to be a definite advantage for the organisms that possessed them  and, thus, are naturally selected and passed down through the generations, or b) they were never selected against. Like, they were there, but no one ever made a big deal out of them, so the gene coding for them just kinda stuck around in the population. (kinda like human males having nipples - they don't serve an evolutionary purpose, but neither are they a detriment to survival, so men just develop them and no one thinks anything different of it).  Gradually, environmental stresses may have favoured the extensive development of feathers into wings the likes of which we see in modern birds, coupled with other mutations and adaptions in the population to produce the little feathery scumbags that sit on your back fence and sing at, like, five in the morning. The important thing to remember is that a species as a whole doesn't spontaneously just sprout feathers. The gene coding for it may or may not be dispersed through the population over time depending on whether or not it's favourable in terms of ensuring the organism's survival.  So, realistically, the dinobird wouldn't have been running around with one wing and one dino arm. It would have had dino arms coated in feathers; feathers that its species acquired veeery gradually as the gene coding for 'feathers' dispersed to affect the entire population. And this beautiful, beautiful process would have, in time, given rise to modern day birds.

ArcaneTruth (theghost)  Abiogenesis would not violate the so-called "law of biogenesis".  1) The so-called "law of biogenesis" is not an inviolate law of nature (like the law of gravity is). Instead, the “law of biogenesis” is an inductive conclusion. The basic logic is as follows: "Every X studied so far has Y, therefore, all X's have Y."  In inductive reasoning, the conclusion cannot be considered reliable.  The conclusion is consistent with the premises, but it does not necessarily follow from them.  Inductive conclusions must be considered tentative, not absolute. The history of science if full of inductive conclusions that later turned out to be wrong. As one example, all the wide variety of cells that had been studied up to a certain point in time used the same genetic code, so it was concluded that it was the UNIVERSAL genetic code, used by all organisms everywhere. But later a few exceptions were found.  2) The so-called "law of biogenesis" is an inductive conclusion based on studies of modern cells, and the first living entity would not have been a modern cell or anything like a modern cell.  So even if for the sake of argument we were to accept that the so-called "law of biogenesis" is 100% absolute, it still wouldn't apply to the origin of life since the "law" was derived from studies of modern cells, which are not what would have been involved in the origin of life.  For example, in one model with some scientific support, the first "cells" (protocells):  a. would not have had any genetically encoded proteins (unlike even the simplest extant cell, which has several hundred genetically encoded proteins)  b. would have had a membrane made of fatty acids (unlike all extant cells, which have a membrane consisting of a phospholipid bilayer – with proteins embedded in it)  c. would have stored its genetic information using RNA (not DNA, as all extant cells use to store their genetic information)  d. would have copied its genetic information using catalytic RNA molecules (not proteins, as all extant cells use to copy their genetic information)  e. would have had only 1 or a handful of genes (unlike even the simplest extant cell, which has several hundred genes).  The studies from which the so-called "law of biogenesis" was derived did not deal with anything like the above protocells, so their findings cannot be taken to apply to such protocells.

For the first question, I believe the idea is that Hox genes are just as susceptible to random mutation as any other gene.  The difference is that Hox gene mutations will have an amplified effect on phenotype due to their "Head Architect" type role.  If the new phenotype is selected for by nature, evolution takes a dramatic step.

To answer the second part of the question, the removal of earlier traits alongside new ones is enough to account for the speed of bird evolution. Additionally, many of those traits were already developing in raptors and their relatives. For example, they had strong legs for jumping. Feathers are first shown from the early Jurassic, millions of years before birds hit the scene.

When we say that two species are genetically similar, we mean as a proportion of the total DNA. When you inherit genes from your parents, you get half of *your* genes from each, but about 99% of those are the same between your parents since they're both human. It's 50% of the traits that weren't already going to be identical.

I love the enthusiasm of this guy, it's a great video, but there are some mistakes. Please note that the terms homeobox and Hox are NOT interchangeable. All Hox genes are homeobox genes, but homeobox genes are not all Hox genes. This video makes a few mistakes because of this confusion.  Yes, Hox genes are some of the homeobox genes that are important during embryogenesis to determine where different body parts develop... but the bit about junk DNA is incorrect. There aren't 100s of Hox genes.

It's always retained in the genome--certain genes just get "turned off" or "inactivated" (and thus the traits get unexpressed) or genes change through mutation. In order to get a new species with new traits, all you need to have is an altered genome. In the case of birds, they happened to get several genes turned off (ones that code for scales, tails, teeth, etc.) while new gene mutations called for the development of wings, beaks, feathers, etc.

arcadesj is right. You should remember that species are naturally selected for to fit in their particular "niche" in their environment; the reason why weasels and bears still live today, even though bears are more badass than weasels, is because bears eat larger prey and weasels eat smaller prey that bears generally couldn't be bothered with. Both species can persist as a result. In addition, in speciation, genetic information is never "lost" or removed. …(continued)
